title: Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Reflux Hypersensitivity
description: Official Rome IV diagnostic criteria for reflux hypersensitivity, a functional esophageal disorder characterized by retrosternal symptoms triggered by normal amounts of gastroesophageal reflux. This validated diagnostic tool distinguishes reflux hypersensitivity from GERD and functional heartburn through specific investigations including pH monitoring with normal acid exposure but positive symptom-reflux association.

parameters.name: retrosternal_symptoms
parameters.description: Retrosternal symptoms including heartburn and chest pain for at least 3 months with onset ≥6 months ago, occurring ≥2 times per week
options: yes - Patient experiences retrosternal symptoms (heartburn and/or chest pain) for the required duration and frequency
no - Patient does not meet the symptom criteria for duration, frequency, or location

parameters.name: normal_endoscopy
parameters.description: Normal endoscopy findings without evidence of erosive esophagitis or other mucosal abnormalities
options: yes - Upper endoscopy shows normal esophageal mucosa without erosions or other abnormalities
no - Upper endoscopy shows erosive esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, or other mucosal lesions

parameters.name: absence_eosinophilic_esophagitis
parameters.description: Absence of evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE) on endoscopy and biopsy
options: yes - No evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis on endoscopy and esophageal biopsies
no - Evidence of eosinophilic esophagitis present on endoscopy or histology

parameters.name: absence_major_motor_disorders
parameters.description: Absence of major esophageal motor disorders (achalasia, EGJ outflow obstruction, diffuse esophageal spasm, jackhammer esophagus, absent peristalsis)
options: yes - No major esophageal motor disorders on manometry or appropriate functional studies
no - Major esophageal motor disorders present on manometry

parameters.name: normal_acid_exposure_with_symptom_association
parameters.description: Evidence of symptom triggering by reflux events despite normal acid exposure on pH or pH-impedance monitoring
options: yes - Normal acid exposure time (<4%) on pH monitoring but positive symptom-reflux association (SAP >95% or SI >50%)
no - Abnormal acid exposure time (≥4%) or negative symptom-reflux association on pH monitoring

parameters.name: exclusion_alarm_symptoms
parameters.description: Exclusion of alarm symptoms requiring further evaluation (dysphagia, weight loss, iron deficiency anemia, persistent vomiting, lymphadenopathy)
options: yes - No alarm symptoms present that would require alternative diagnostic evaluation
no - Alarm symptoms present requiring further clinical evaluation before diagnosis

result.name: rome_iv_reflux_hypersensitivity_diagnosis
result.description: Rome IV diagnostic assessment for reflux hypersensitivity based on fulfillment of all required criteria

ranges.description: Does not meet Rome IV criteria
ranges.interpretation: Patient does not fulfill Rome IV diagnostic criteria for reflux hypersensitivity. One or more essential criteria are not met. Consider alternative diagnoses including GERD with abnormal acid exposure, functional heartburn with negative symptom-reflux association, eosinophilic esophagitis, or major esophageal motor disorders. Complete appropriate investigations including upper endoscopy, esophageal manometry, and ambulatory pH monitoring as indicated.

Patient fulfills Rome IV diagnostic criteria for reflux hypersensitivity. Diagnosis is established when all criteria are met including retrosternal symptoms, normal endoscopy, exclusion of eosinophilic esophagitis and motor disorders, and demonstration of normal acid exposure with positive symptom-reflux association. Treatment may include acid suppression therapy, visceral pain modulators, psychological interventions, and lifestyle modifications. Consider neuromodulators for refractory symptoms.

references: Aziz Q, Fass R, Gyawali CP, Miwa H, Pandolfino JE, Zerbib F. Esophageal disorders. Gastroenterology. 2016 May;150(6):1368-1379. doi: 10.1053/j.gastro.2016.02.012.
Rome Foundation. Rome IV Diagnostic Criteria for Functional Gastrointestinal Disorders. 4th ed. Raleigh, NC: Rome Foundation; 2016.
Patel A, Gyawali CP. Reflux hypersensitivity: Current concepts and future directions. Current Gastroenterology Reports. 2015 May;17(5):20. doi: 10.1007/s11894-015-0441-x.
Savarino E, de Bortoli N, De Cassan C, et al. The natural history of gastro-esophageal reflux disease: a comprehensive review. Dis Esophagus. 2017 Feb 1;30(2):1-9. doi: 10.1111/dote.12511.
formula: Rome IV Reflux Hypersensitivity Diagnosis = ALL criteria must be met for ≥3 months (onset ≥6 months ago, ≥2x/week): (1) Retrosternal symptoms + (2) Normal endoscopy + (3) No eosinophilic esophagitis + (4) No major motor disorders + (5) Normal acid exposure with positive symptom-reflux association + (6) No alarm symptoms

Rome IV Reflux Hypersensitivity Diagnosis = ALL criteria must be met for ≥3 months (onset ≥6 months ago, ≥2x/week): (1) Retrosternal symptoms + (2) Normal endoscopy + (3) No eosinophilic esophagitis + (4) No major motor disorders + (5) Normal acid exposure with positive symptom-reflux association + (6) No alarm symptoms
notes: Rome IV diagnostic criteria for functional esophageal disorders
All criteria must be fulfilled for positive diagnosis
Reflux hypersensitivity is a functional esophageal disorder distinct from GERD
Requires ambulatory pH or pH-impedance monitoring for diagnosis
Normal acid exposure time defined as <4% total time pH <4.0
Positive symptom-reflux association: SAP >95% or SI >50%
Symptom association probability (SAP) and symptom index (SI) are key parameters
Distinguished from GERD by normal acid exposure time
Distinguished from functional heartburn by positive symptom-reflux association
May respond to acid suppression therapy despite normal acid exposure
Visceral pain modulators (tricyclics, gabapentinoids) may be effective
Psychological interventions and stress management are important
Dietary modifications similar to GERD management may help
Prokinetic agents may be considered for symptom management
Post-reflux swallow-induced peristaltic wave (PSPW) index may provide additional diagnostic value
Mean nocturnal baseline impedance (MNBI) may help identify reflux hypersensitivity
Controversial classification - some experts consider it part of GERD spectrum
